author: Oliver Pritchett
title: How much should you tip in different situations?
text: Some advice on the tricky business of tipping : In church, there is a service charge, which you pay by contributing to the collection, but it is also customary to give a gratuity to the vicar for the sermon, the usual rate being 75p per minute, but it can be 85p in a “high” church. At the zoo, one is expected to reward the crocodiles for lying very still and playing dead. A few coins tossed into their pool will be appreciated. When you check into your hotel room, the porter will hang around after showing you where the bed is, how the bathroom taps work, where the ironing board is kept, how the curtains open and close, etc. He appreciates it if you reciprocate by demonstrating the clever way your suitcase zips up. Photo: Paul Grover The cup by the till in Starbucks invites you to express your gratitude with loose change. Because of the company’s complicated tax arrangements , it prefers foreign coins, a few US cents or pre-euro centimes. If you don’t have foreign coins, an Isle of Man 10p will do. After the delivery men have carried the piano to your first floor, they will be perfectly satisfied if you give them a tune. Often they will sing along. If you disagree with your taxi driver’s political views, you may halve his tip. He will see this as a mark of respect. “Reverse tipping” is catching on in parts of the country. When leaving a restaurant, if you feel your treatment has been offhand, you may help yourself to a £2 coin from the cloakroom saucer. And if you come across a busker whose playing is truly dreadful, you should take some money from the collection by his feet as a fine. @telegoodlife
